title: My screenwriting professor said the most important part of a screenplay is having it in the correct format because they’ll throw any screenplay away without reading it if it has even one formatting mistake. Is this true? - Quora

response.answer_text: A formatting mistake is exceptionally indicative that you are not fluent in the business because software has been available for 20 years for relatively little money to assure the correct formats are used. It’s not an exceptionally difficult format. If you’re self-producing, you don’t need to follow the format, but here are some issues that come up as more difficult if you do not use a good format. Both the Screen Actors Guild and the Writers Guild of America define contracts in terms of lines of text in the screenplay. In the WGA world, if you ask the writer to rewrite more than twice or three times, it’s considered an implicit contract. To straighten out the script for the purposes of analysis within the contexts of those two unions — SAG and WGA — uses up one of those rewrites. There are probably other considerations as well. For example, with the format, the general guideline of one page of text is approximately one minute of film is often assumed. So … if you don’t follow the format, you’re not only displaying your unfamiliarity with the industry and the craft, you’ve complicated the rewriting process, you’ve started down the path of having issues with SAG and WGA, AND, the producer doesn’t have a rough idea of how long your movie is going to be.

EVERYTHING has basically already been said…. BUT I’ll add this. By following format it helps measure the timing of the length which helps them determine the budget. Locations can can run $10k a day, cinematographers are over $600 a day, etc etc. hell, even a union extra can make $400 a day. when there’s millions and billions riding on it - format - with regards to measuring timing and budget are imperative. UNLESS you are making it and funding it. Clerks is a great example of something that was a hit and broke all the rules - it was also self funded and more expensive than it looks. Formatting is also derived from Greek theatre where holding people’s attention was a matter of getting rotten produce thrown at you. Have you ever seen a movie that wasn’t bad but wasn’t good but you can’t really place what’s wrong with it….? it’s likely because specific plot points got missed. They are subtle, but every blockbuster has them.

I’ve never been one to let someone get away with laziness - especially when it comes to screenwriting. People expect me to be worth the money they pay me, so I have no qualms at all at asking you: Who is ‘they’ exactly? I only ask because there’s only one scenario were “they” will throw “any screenplay” away, and that if it’s an unsolicited manuscript. If someone asks to see your screenplay, they’re going to read it. No reader wants to be the one who passed on the next Iron Man or Matrix because there was a formatting mistake in the screenplay. That being said, don’t go off half cocked. You should ALWAYS put your best foot forward - whether you’re a noob or a seasoned professional - because it shows that you care about your product.

I'm not sure it's the "most important thing", but formatting errors communicate one or more of the following: You don't know the business.You don't care enough to research the requirements for submission.You don't think rules apply to you.Which of these do you think would make them want to work with you?
